                            A: Seed systems are vital for maintaining crop biodiversity, stimulating demand for high-quality seeds, and ensuring successful crop production.
                            Q: What are the two main types of seed systems?
                            A: The two main types are formal seed systems and informal seed systems.
                            Q: What is the formal seed system?
                            A: Formal seed systems are deliberately constructed, involving a chain of activities leading to certified seed of verified varieties.
                            Q: What are the guiding principles of the formal seed system?
                            A: The guiding principles are maintenance of varietal identity and genetic purity, and production of seed with optimal physical, physiological, and sanitary qualities.
                            Q: What is the central premise of the formal seed system?
                            A: The central premise is that there is a clear distinction between seed and grain.
                            Q: What is the informal seed system?
                            A: Informal seed systems are also referred to as local, traditional, or farmer seed systems, where farmers produce, disseminate, and access seed directly from their own harvest.
                            Q: What characterizes informal seed systems?
                            A: Informal seed systems are characterized by their flexibility and encompass a wide range of variations.
                            Q: What are the sources of seed in informal seed systems?
                            A: Seeds in informal systems come from farmers' own harvest, exchange and barter among friends, neighbors, and relatives, and local grain markets.
                            Q: What is the role of farmers in informal seed systems?
                            A: Farmers play a crucial role in producing, disseminating, and accessing seed in informal systems.
                            Q: What is the integrated seed system?
                            A: The integrated seed system is a complementary system that makes the seed system more holistic and pluralistic, meeting the diverse needs of farmers.}

  "Q: How do farmers ensure synchrony between the flowering of male and female parents?"

  "A: Cold weather reduces pollen viability and causes erratic seed set in late planted crops."

  "Q: How does high moisture and humidity affect pollen sacks?"
  "A: Pollen sacks do not dry out fast enough, their skin becomes rubbery, and they do not split and shed pollen."

  "Q: What is the effect of temperatures below 10°C and above 40°C on pollen viability?"
  "A: Temperatures below 10°C and above 40°C definitely reduce pollen viability."

  "Q: What is the purpose of spraying Thiram/Captan to control sugary disease (ergot)?"
  "A: To control the disease and avoid prolonged sowings in the same areas, since the disease may invade the late sown crop in epiphytotic proportion."

  "Q: How can farmers make the available pollen to achieve good seed set?"
  "A: By careful manipulation of nitrogenous fertilizers, foliar spray of GA, and irrigation."

{ Q: What is the purpose of biofortification in agriculture?
                            A: Biofortification is a food-based approach to reduce micronutrient malnutrition among the poor population.
                            Q: What are the benefits of biofortification?
                            A: It provides a long-term strategy of delivering more micronutrients and is a powerful intervention tool to alleviate micronutrient malnourishment.
                            Q: How does biofortification improve nutrition?
                            A: Biofortified crop varieties can be developed through conventional breeding programmes, and once developed, there is no additional expense involved in getting higher nutrition.
                            Q: Which crops are suitable for biofortification?
                            A: Millets are highly nutritious and can be biofortified to improve their nutritional content.
                            Q: What are the nutritional benefits of millets?
                            A: Millets are rich in protein, fibre, micro and macronutrients, and are gluten-free.
                            Q: Which millet has the highest content of fat and micronutrients?
                            A: Pearl millet has the highest content of fat and micronutrients.
                            Q: Which millet is a cheap source of energy, protein, iron, and zinc?
                            A: Sorghum is a cheap source of energy, protein, iron, and zinc.
                            Q: Which millet is the richest source of calcium and potassium?
                            A: Finger millet is the richest source of calcium and potassium.
                            Q: What are the health benefits of consuming millets?
                            A: Millets have been found to be helpful in the treatment of diabetes, obesity, blood pressure, heart diseases, cancer, etc., and act as immune boosters due to the presence of vitamins and essential minerals.
